record.text: iOS and X use “Mitteilungen” while Facebook and Instagram use “Benachrichtigungen”, so I guess either of those should be ok. “Mitteilungen” risks being confused with DMs (although I’d translate DMs as “Nachrichten”). I wouldn’t use “Meldungen” or the English word, as some suggested.
is "Benachrichtigungen" really the shortest german word available for notifications?
is "Benachrichtigungen" really the shortest german word available for notifications?

record.text:
I wrote up a blog post on our findings with scaling Go to 192 cores per machine and the limits we ran into with the Go runtime here: jazco.dev/2024/01/10/g...

It was a really interesting problem to investigate and had us scratching our heads for a little bit but the performance gains are huge.

external.description: When running on baremetal, however, we found two key limitations of the Go runtime so far: Systems with a lot of RAM can have a lot of allocations, prompting the Go Garbage Collector to aggressively s...
external.title: Scaling Golang to 192 Cores with Heavy I/O

external.description: When running on baremetal, however, we found two key limitations of the Go runtime so far: Systems with a lot of RAM can have a lot of allocations, prompting the Go Garbage Collector to aggressively s...
external.title: Scaling Golang to 192 Cores with Heavy I/O

value.text:
Things i did not expect would ever be a problem when writing @ scale software in Go:

Go's runtime only scales well to a certain number of cores and memory size.

Especially for I/O heavy apps, Go's EPoll buffer size is small enough that you end up burning 80% of your CPU waiting on EPoll syscalls.

record.text: tl;dr doing hardware attacks on a HSM that spins is hard. if you tried to stop it from spinning, it'd detect that and erase the key material.
they actually did this, unironically tches.iacr.org/index.php/TC...

record.text: Standard Notes has a nicer user interface (in my opinion), but I ran into some problems with it: no official Notion importer (I tried writing my own, with partial success); notes with formatting ("super") use some kind of custom file format; embedded images are not included iin backups. All fixable

I've long wanted to move my ~4,000 personal notes (a key part of my research workflow) out of Notion and into something better. I did some testing with Standard Notes and Obsidian, and eventually settled on Obsidian. Pretty happy with it: markdown, local-first, encrypted sync, fast search.

Academic spam can be entertaining. Here is a journal that will accept any article that is at most 15% plagiarised 🤪

images.alt:
Screenshot of a spam email:

Dear Professor | Scientist | Scholar,

You are invited to submit original research article(s) as per your research expertise. Article(s) can be submitted from the journal website by using the "Article Submission System" throughout the year if:

• Plagiarism of the article is less tthan 15%, including references.
• The articles are within the scope of the journal.
• The article is original and result-oriented.
• For more detailed information, please visit "Guidelines for Authors".

Warmest regards.
Editor-In-Chief

Screenshot of a spam email:

Dear Professor | Scientist | Scholar,

You are invited to submit original research article(s) as per your research expertise. Article(s) can be submitted from the journal website by using the "Article Submission System" throughout the year if:

• Plagiarism of the article is less tthan 15%, including references.
• The articles are within the scope of the journal.
• The article is original and result-oriented.
• For more detailed information, please visit "Guidelines for Authors".

Warmest regards.
Editor-In-Chief

images.alt:
A comic of two foxes, one of whom is blue, the other is green. In this one, Blue sits among an assortment of various miscellaneous objects, as Green keeps carrying more and more things on and around him.
Blue: ...What are you doing?
Green: I'm gathering a pile of all my favourite things.
Blue: On me?
Green: Of course. I can't carry you into the pile, so I must gather the pile on you.

record.text: People talk about imperative vs declarative programming but it really should be algorithmic vs declarative. Imperative and functional programming are algorithmic, while logic programming, constraint solving, and query languages are declarative.
It seems to be common for Germans to criticise others for silly things. I remember a friend telling me that she got told off by a neighbour for leaving a window in her apartment open in the winter
that sounds like the worst 😔 i’m surprised germans will get up in your business like that, rather than judge silently

An annoying thing about being a parent in Germany is receiving unsolicited parenting criticism from random strangers on the street (“your baby’s hat is not warm enough!”, “he’s leaning his head too far backwards!”, etc). It’s always women who do this. Would it be fair to call it “momsplaining”?

pretty incredible. 147 years after Charles Babbage came up with the design for the Difference Engine No. 2, Doron Swade at the London Science Museum publishes a user manual and technical details for the machine! www.sciencemuseum.org.uk/sites/defaul...

front facing view of a reconstruction of Charles Babbage's Difference Engine 2.

record.text:
The "effective altruism" and "effective accelerationism" ideologies that have been cropping up in AI debates are just a thin veneer over the typical blend of Silicon Valley techno-utopianism, inflated egos, and greed. Let's try something else.

newsletter.mollywhite.net/p/effective-...

external.description: Silicon Valley's "effective altruism" and "effective accelerationism" only give a thin philosophical veneer to the industry's same old impulses.
external.title: Effective obfuscation

external.description: Silicon Valley's "effective altruism" and "effective accelerationism" only give a thin philosophical veneer to the industry's same old impulses.

Very excited to share our paper on private user discovery in anonymity networks, accepted at IEEE S&P 2024 🍮 Check out Pudding on arXiv!

value.text:
Two new papers went up on arxiv today! 📄✨

1. Pudding: Private User Discovery in Anonymity Networks arxiv.org/abs/2311.10825 🍮

We extend the Loopix/Nym anonymity network with privacy-preserving, human-friendly usernames. This paper is accepted at IEEE S&P 2024.

external.description: Anonymity networks allow messaging with metadata privacy, providing better privacy than popular encrypted messaging applications. However, contacting a user on an anonymity network currently...
external.title: Pudding: Private User Discovery in Anonymity Networks

record.text:
2. The Art of the Fugue: Minimizing Interleaving in Collaborative Text Editing arxiv.org/abs/2305.00583 🎼

Many collaborative text editing algorithms interleave text that two users insert at the same position. We formally analyse the problem and fix it. (Revision of a paper from earlier this year)

record.text: it's maybe a little myopic to mention, but from my perspective of working on decentralization for about 10 years--trying and failing--I can't believe any of this is happening. I can't believe the tech is working. I can't believe people are using it. I can't believe I'm working with the people I am

looking at it now in comparison, I feel pretty fortunate. there are a million things to get done and improve on, but we've been straight up blessed, I love our community, and I'm extremely confident in the team

Hi @jay.bsky.team. 

Wow, coming up to nearly a year since you posted this. Congrats on Bluesky. I think it’s bringing people together. 

If you get the chance I’d love to hear your honest take on how you think things are now compared to this time last year. Has your vision for Bluesky materialised?

value.text:
bluesky’s culture is just beginning. what will we build, here? 

we’re building on a different kind of foundation, where what happened to twitter can never happen to us, if we do our job right.

Yesterday Trump posted this. Also yesterday, I visited the Dachau concentration camp memorial site, and… let's just say, the rhetoric sounds eerily familiar. The US today is not the Weimar republic of a century ago, but nevertheless it's worrying.

images.alt: Screenshot of Trump post on Truth Social: “…we pledge to you that we will root out the Communists, Marxists, Fascists, and Radical Left Thugs that live like vermin within the confines of our Country, lie, steal, and cheat on Elections…” and “The threat from outside forces is far less sinister, dangerous, and grave, than the threat from within.”

Screenshot of Trump post on Truth Social: “…we pledge to you that we will root out the Communists, Marxists, Fascists, and Radical Left Thugs that live like vermin within the confines of our Country, lie, steal, and cheat on Elections…” and “The threat from outside forces is far less sinister, dangerous, and grave, than the threat from within.”

record.text: Reflecting on this in the light of the conflicts raging today, causing so much grief

This is the wall of the university library in Munich. The damage is from bullets and shrapnel during World War II, and it has been left unrepaired as a war memorial. Of course much worse damage to buildings and people happened elsewhere, which makes this simple wall a poignant understatement.

images.alt: A red brick wall of a building, with lots of damaged bricks all over. There is a bicycle in a corner. Part of the wall is covered with a pane of glass on which is written: “Wunden der Erinnerung” (wounds of remembrance). A lone tulip hangs from the glass pane.

A red brick wall of a building, with lots of damaged bricks all over. There is a bicycle in a corner. Part of the wall is covered with a pane of glass on which is written: “Wunden der Erinnerung” (wounds of remembrance). A lone tulip hangs from the glass pane.

record.text: This is the wall of the university library in Munich. The damage is from bullets and shrapnel during World War II, and it has been left unrepaired as a war memorial. Of course much worse damage to buildings and people happened elsewhere, which makes this simple wall a poignant understatement.
